title: Ancient temple revealed after drought drains reservoir in Mexico | Metro News
text:
Toby Meyjes for Metro.co.uk Thursday 16 Feb 2017 9:47 am The church was submerged in the reservoir in the 1960s (Picture: CEN) 
A drought has revealed a 400-year-old Dominican church that has remained intact despite spending decades underwater in a reservoir in Mexico. 
The church, which was submerged in the 1960s when the nearby Benito Juarez Dam was built, partially reappears every year. Group of Orthodox Jews removed from flight for refusing to sit with women 
However, a severe drought in Mexico has caused the water level to drop so much the temple is now almost completely visible. 
Drone footage has shown that despite remaining underwater for so long much of the stone structure beneath the surface is still completely intact. 
The church was built in the late 1500s by monks and nuns as they arrived in Mexico to spread Christianity. To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video The drought has caused problems for local farmers (Picture: CEN) Although it becomes partially visible every years the temple is rarely completely seen (Picture: CEN) The structure has remained completely intact (Picture: CEN) The church was last revealed in 2008 when a drought hit the region (Picture: CEN) 
Tour guide and fisherman Miguel Oliveira told RT : ‘This temple is believed to have been built between 1550 and 1600. 
‘Here was venerated the virgin Mary of assumption. She is the patroness of Santa María Jalapa de Márquez,’ 
The dam was built in 1962 to boost agriculture in the south east of Mexico by increasing the availability of water. 
However, while revealing the church, the severe drought has put hundreds of corn producers under threat. 
The temple was also almost completely revealed in 2008 when a critical drought has caused the water level to recede. More
